info.game_comments:
(Jimmy: We're visiting one of the longest-running musicals in Broadway history.)
(Cheryl: Come along and be our guest, next on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: This Daniel Defoe hero is "thrown into a violent calenture"--a fever once said to affect sailors in the Tropics

(2, 1).clue: David Letterman walked Oprah to the opening of this musical based on an Alice Walker novel

(3, 1).clue: During the 1992 L.A. riots, one of these worn by Madonna in a video was stolen from Frederick's of Hollywood

(4, 1).clue: "To those critics who are so pessimistic about our economy, I say, don't be economic girlie men!"

(5, 1).clue: Shortly after establishing a lab in Menlo Park, N.J., he invented the carbon telephone transmitter

(6, 1).clue: This branch of medicine is from the Greek for "mind cure"

(1, 2).clue: In "The Europeans" Gertrude wears a "quaint and charming leghorn" one of these, "tied with white satin bows"

(2, 2).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre in New York.)  I'm here on the Broadway set on which you'll hear Mrs. Potts sing this title tune"Tale as old as time /True as it can be..."

(3, 2).clue: In the 1960s women would puff out their hair in this style, French for "full" or "puffed"

(4, 2).clue: "I spent several years in a North Vietnamese prison camp... you think I want to do that all over again as vice president?"

(5, 2).clue: In 1936 he wrote a paper for the Smithsonian entitled "Liquid-Propellant Rocket Development"

(6, 2).clue: Spread it around--it goes back to a Greek word for "cow cheese"

(1, 3).clue: In "A Tale of Two Cities", Jerry Cruncher is a "resurrection-man"--defined as a person who steals & sells these

(2, 3).clue: "Big Girls Don’t Cry" over "Jersey Boys", a musical bio of this '60s group that had its peaks & "Valli"s

(3, 3).clue: In the 1800s women would puff out their skirts by wearing this padding or framework underneath

(4, 3).clue: Regarding the attacks on his son: "If Barbara gets her hands on John Kerry, he might get another Purple Heart"

(5, 3).clue: In 1815 he built America's first steam-powered warship

(6, 3).clue: The name of these sometimes nasty microscopic life forms is from the Greek for "little rod"

(1, 4).clue: In "Emma", Emma speaks of being in Broadway-lane when "it began to mizzle", which means this

(2, 4).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew reads from the Shubert Theatre in New York.)  The creators of "Spamalot" proudly proclaim that it is "lovingly ripped off" from this be-knighted British film
(2, 4).correct response: Monty Python and the Holy Grail

(3, 4).clue: This short jacket worn open in the front is perfect for listening to Ravel's music of the same name

(4, 4).clue: "I want to thank the Canadian people who came out to wave, with all five fingers, for their hospitality"

(5, 4).clue: By early 1895, at his estate near Bologna, he could ring a bell a few yards away via radio waves

(6, 4).clue: This elevated Athens area appropriately comes from 2 Greek words meaning "highest city"

(1, 5).clue: "What a mommet of a maid!" (mommet meaning scarecrow) is said of this Thomas Hardy title character

(3, 5).clue: The USA's oldest clothing retailer, this upscale, once family-run business has collared the market on men's apparel since 1818

(4, 5).clue: Secretary of Health and Human Services: "For the life of me, I cannot understand why the terrorists have not attacked our food supply"

(5, 5).clue: Around 1862 this American locksmith introduced a dial-operated combination lock for bank vaults

(6, 5).clue: One of the sacraments established by Christ; its "holy" name is from the Greek for "grateful"

(1, 1).clue: Ownership of the Kuril Islands to Japan's north is disputed between Japan & this nation

(2, 1).clue: In 1934, Claudette Colbert played this Egyptian; in 1963, Elizabeth Taylor did

(3, 1).clue: In 1975 Angola gained its independence from this colonial power

(4, 1).clue: The name of this appetizer seen here means "before the food"

(5, 1).clue: Alors!  It is a complete & utter disgrace zat zees "Nutty Professor" has not been Oscar nominated

(1, 2).clue: In 1995 this "beefy" capital of Hyogo prefecture was hit by a 7.2 earthquake

(2, 2).clue: Indy seeks to solve a biblical mystery in this 1981 film that features a quest from Nepal to Cairo

(3, 2).clue: In the 1970s this Caribbean country sent several thousand troops to fight in Angola's civil war

(4, 2).clue: In Italian cuisine this meat is traditionally the most popular to cook "cacciatore" or "hunter style"

(5, 2).clue: Mon dieu!  Zees man has been ze French chief of state for 10 full years!

(1, 3).clue: The seaport of Naha is on this Japanese island that was the site of a fierce WWII battle in April 1945

(2, 3).clue: Boris Karloff was under wraps as this title Egyptian in a 1932 film

(3, 3).clue: Around 2,000 years ago, members of this large African ethnolinguistic group began settling in Angola

(4, 3).clue: A nice addition to any Italian meal is this Tuscan wine seen here in its distinctive packaging

(5, 3).clue: Sacre bleu!  Eet takes so long sailing from Dover to zees closest French port; next time, I take zee Chunnel

(1, 4).clue: 2 of the 4 main islands of Japan

(2, 4).clue: Rita Hayworth makes a short, sultry appearance in the 1935 film about this Asian detective “in Egypt”

(3, 4).clue: Today a city of 2 1/2 million, this capital city was founded in 1576

(4, 4).clue: Vitello tonnato is this meat cooked in a tuna & mayonnaise puree

(5, 4).clue: Surely you joke, no?  Zees defensive pre-WWII "line" on ze German border was perfect until ze Belgians caved

(6, 4).clue: "Children are not rugged individualists", wrote Hillary Clinton in this bestselling book

(2, 5).clue: In this 1994 film, an interstellar-teleportation device found in Egypt leads humans to a distant planet

(3, 5).clue: Angola's borders were not fixed until 1926 & the resolution of a dispute with what's now this nation due south

(4, 5).clue: When you're ready for dessert, leave the gun & take these favorites seen here

(5, 5).clue: Don’t blame us for shooting zo many of Gen. Braddock’s men during zis war; zay wore red coats in ze green forest!

(6, 5).clue: This freaky 1960 film starring George Sanders concerned a town where children used mysterious powers on adults

(0, 0).clue: In 1839 the first of several wars broke out over the trade of an extract from a flower of this family
